transcripts.text: Let's get the player Snoop in real quick.  What's up, Snoop?
Black man, what's happening?
What's up, Pim Jus?  How you doing, Black?
I'm in slow motion, man.  Just checking game.  Messing with y'all.  Spit that game.  You know what I'm saying?  Showing support.
My man, I respect that, brother.  You in the studio right now?
You already know it.  Can't stop, won't stop.
Oh, man.  What new project you working on?

I got a little something I'm working on.  I really can't say what it is, but it's something special.  I've actually formed a group with three other brothers like myself, and we about to put something together to really, you know, get a game, something special.
So is it going to be like R&B?
No, no, no, no, no.  This is gangster shit.
Okay, okay.

We can't be on the R&B right about now.  We need to, you understand me, put our foot to the pedal right now, you know what I'm saying?  And say what we need to say, because a lot of us been saying it for many years, but we've been getting pushed to the side because they like, every nigga say the same old thing, yeah, whatever, whatever.  But now it's like, it's actually visible.  you can see what we were saying.  so it's just a follow-up.  it's a follow-up to what's actually out there and what the change need to be and what the change is going to be because we refuse to go back to what it was exactly exactly.
how do you feel about the the protest and everything that's going on especially out here in la?

actually i love it.  i love it that it's mixed and it's a lot of others out there pushing the cause.  And to me, that's when it starts becoming something special when it affects you like it affects me.  We know what it do to black people.  We already know what it do.  We tired of marching and protesting and all that.  We ready to go to the next level.  So to see others step up and be on the front line and willing to do that and take that to the next level for us and to stand by us and to really meaning to be sincere, that's when you will get change.
Now, you were around during the 92 joint.  I remember y'all with Matt McDaniel and all that.

I was a different player then.  I was a soldier then.  I was a frontliner.  That's why I say you got to know your role when you play your position.  So right now, my position is being vocal, being wisdom, being understanding, being strategic, being a platform, being a voice, being all of the things that the youngsters can't be.  You understand me?  So they got to be the soldiers, the activists, the ones that's pushing the line out there protesting because somebody got to do somebody's job.  And that's my job to do the up top that y'all can't do.  To get those conversations with the governors and the mayors and the police chiefs and to be able to sit down with them and speak from our perspective and get some real change.
Yes, exactly.  Exactly.  Do you think that the relationship between the police is going to get better with us out here?

I think it has to, because what I'm not seeing is, and I've been saying this for many years, is that, and this is some crazy shit when I say it, why don't they never let Black police, police, black neighborhood.
Exactly.

Like, that shit right there just blows my mind that you would rather send some untrained white officers who are timid to begin with into a black neighborhood and they already got the bad report that he's on parole, he's this, he's that.  So they coming in with a negative attitude as opposed to having a black officer who may know my mother, my uncle, me, my sister, my grandmama.  He may know somebody in my family.  He may be my family.  He may just send me holiday real quick.  Let me get him right.  He ain't that bad.  Let me chop it up with him.  Because I notice how they do a whole lot of chopping it up with they people when it's time to bring them in and, you know, put handcuffs on them.

Yeah, yeah, yeah.  It's heavy out here.  How do you feel, man?  I've been complaining about the lack of a lot of black lawyers who could help out with a lot of the legislation.  At one point, you had the best lawyer in modern history, Johnny Cochran, represented you, brother.
Yes, sir.
Why do you think we don't have any type of Johnny Cochran type of brothers now out here representing?  What do you think the problem is?

I think the problem is that's not promoted.  Ain't nobody promoting that.  You know, we're promoting hip hop and rapping and sports and athletics and entertainment, but nobody's pressing the issue on that line.  And to me, that begins with the HBCUs.  If you start sending kids to those HBCUs, then you'll get more lawyers and more people in that field because that's what breeds that, you know, a bunch of brilliant black minds.  And that's why me and my boys, we're on a mission to try to sway some of these kids to start looking at some of these HBCU universities and giving them an opportunity to, you know, get action at some of these athletes and some of these black brilliant minds.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.  You still doing the football, coaching the football?

Man, I can't stop.  I've been doing that since 2005.  We're sending kids every day.  And now, for the past three years, we've been doing the Snoop Special Star, so we deal with special needs kids.  So we've been, you know, giving them the attention that they deserve and getting them to come outside and interacting with them and, you know, creating an avenue of love and expression for the special needs kids.  And it's been going on for three years, and it's a beautiful thing.
That's beautiful, man.  I want to contribute something to that too, man, if y'all got a website, because that's a beautiful thing.
Yes, sir.
I'm working on a new documentary talking about manhood, things that we need to do as black men.  I want to get you a part of it, man.

I'm in.  I'm in.  I'm a fan.  Look, let me tell you, look.  my homeboy put me up on you man.  one of my homies was like man.  you got to get up on.  you got to get up on him.  dog he cold check him out.  so he tried to put me up on a book or something that you had did a documentary.  so i'm like.  i don't want to.  i want to know everything about him.  don't send me his product.  i want to know about him.  and i researched you and i looked you up and i seen what you about.  and i'm on your team.  i'm one of your players.  i'm one of your brothers.
i'm with you Man, man, much respect to that, man.  You talking Dane Funk lately?
Man, that's my guy from Pasadena where the grass is greener.
That's my nigga, ain't it?
You better know it.

My man.  But yeah, hit me in the DM, man.  I'm going to reach out to you so we can organize this stuff, man.  And I appreciate you, Snoop, man.  Also, let me know about the special needs thing so I can contribute to that, man.  That's such a beautiful thing.  We need brothers getting on top of that.

You know, I don't really do it for publicity.  So that's probably why people don't really hear about it.  And really, it was kind of embarrassing for the parents and the people that were dealing with the kids in the beginning.  So I didn't really want to put too much attention on it.  until I got them comfortable with, you know, being able to express that this, we need to speak on it.  We need to let people know who have special needs kids that we have things for them to do instead of just always locking them in a room and not giving them no fun and not knowing how to deal with them.  They start screaming or whatever they're doing.  You don't know how to deal with it.  The doctor's not giving you the right information.  So it's like, bring them to us so we can show them love because love heals everything.
No doubt.  No doubt.  My man, I appreciate this new man.  You have a good night, brother.
You too, black man.
